questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman with a history of chronic sun exposure presented with bilateral brownish pigmentation over the face as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Melasma, especially in pregnant women, presents as bilateral, symmetrical brownish patches on the face, often linked to sun exposure and hormonal changes.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic was admitted to the hospital for 2 days. On the 3rd day, the doctor noted agitation, confusion, disorientation, hallucination, hypertension, and sweating. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Delirium tremens

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Delirium tremens is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal that typically occurs 2 to 3 days after the last drink and includes symptoms like agitation, confusion, hallucinations, hypertension, and sweating.

questions.explanation:

questions.text: A patient presented with severe back ache and the following x-ray after an RTA. Diagnose the fracture present. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.  B) Chance fracture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A Chance fracture is a flexion-distraction injury that extends through all three columns of the spine and is commonly seen in patients who experience a sudden forward motion, such as in a seatbelt-related injury during a car accident.

questions.text: A Child presents with asymmetric crying face and inability to close the left eye as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Facial nerve palsy

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Match the following : (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) A-SVC, B-Aorta, C-Trachea, D-Esophagus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Complex 4 inhibitor is? ( NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cyanide

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Cyanide is a potent inhibitor of Complex IV (cytochrome c oxidase) in the electron transport chain (ETC). Complex IV is crucial for the final step of the electron transport chain, where it facilitates the transfer of electrons to oxygen, the final electron acceptor, to form water. By inhibiting Complex IV, cyanide prevents the reduction of oxygen, halting ATP production and leading to cellular hypoxia and energy failure.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Carbon Dioxide: Carbon dioxide is not an inhibitor of any of the electron transport chain complexes. It is a byproduct of cellular respiration and does not interfere with the function of the ETC complexes.
  • • Option B. Carbon Dioxide:
  • • Option C. Oligomycin: Oligomycin is an inhibitor of ATP synthase (Complex V) in the electron transport chain. It binds to the F0 subunit of ATP synthase, blocking the proton channel and preventing proton translocation across the inner mitochondrial membrane. This inhibition halts ATP synthesis from ADP and inorganic phosphate.
  • • Option C. Oligomycin:
  • • Option D. Antimycin: Antimycin is an inhibitor of Complex III (cytochrome bc1 complex) in the electron transport chain. It binds to the Qi site of cytochrome c reductase, blocking the transfer of electrons from ubiquinol to cytochrome c, disrupting the proton gradient and halting ATP synthesis.
  • • Option D. Antimycin:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Inhibitor of ETC complexes
  • ➤ Inhibitor of ETC complexes

References:

  • ↳ Reference : Harper’s 31 st ed/pg- 123

questions.text: A patient presents to you with an irregularly irregular pulse of 120/minute and a pulse deficit of 20. Which of the following would be the JVP finding? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In atrial fibrillation, the jugular venous pulse (JVP) typically shows an absent a wave due to the lack of coordinated atrial contraction.

questions.text: A patient has undergone laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Identify the structure as marked? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, it is crucial to identify the cystic artery and the cystic duct within Calot's triangle to prevent injury to the biliary structures and ensure a safe surgical procedure.

questions.text: Which ion is most responsible for the resting membrane potential (RMP): (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The resting membrane potential is primarily determined by the concentration gradient of potassium ions (K+) across the cell membrane and the membrane's permeability to K+.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with motor traffic accident with BP 90/60mm Hg. On examination, he was stable with GCS 15/15. The pupil was reactive to light. Tenderness and bruising over the left lower chest wall with petechia were seen. What is the next step? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. eFAST

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The next step in the evaluation of a trauma patient with the given findings is the Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma (eFAST). This non-invasive imaging technique is crucial for rapidly identifying free fluid and organ injuries in the abdomen, as well as potential pneumothorax or hemothorax, which are critical in trauma cases. eFAST is used to quickly assess both stable and unstable patients following blunt abdominal trauma, providing immediate information that can dictate further management steps.
  • • both stable and unstable patients
  • • Details:
  • • Details:
  • • eFAST Role: This ultrasound examination checks for free intraperitoneal or pericardial fluid and can evaluate the integrity of the pleural spaces.
  • • eFAST Role:
  • • Stability: Despite the patient's low blood pressure, he is neurologically intact (GCS 15/15) and responsive, which allows for an ultrasound examination before more invasive procedures are considered.
  • • Stability:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Exploratory laparotomy: Generally reserved for patients showing signs of hemodynamic instability after eFAST or when eFAST is positive for intra-abdominal injury needing surgical intervention.
  • • Option A. Exploratory laparotomy:
  • • Option B. Intubation: Might be necessary if respiratory status worsens or if advanced airway management is required, but the patient’s current stable neurological status does not immediately warrant this.
  • • Option B. Intubation:
  • • Option D. CECT (Contrast Enhanced CT Scan): Used after eFAST if the patient remains hemodynamically stable and further detailed evaluation of internal injuries is necessary.
  • • Option D. CECT (Contrast Enhanced CT Scan):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 6-months-old child presented with cyanosis and fatigue. His chest X ray is shown below. What is the most likely sign and diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Snowman sign, Supracardiac TAPVC

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given X-ray shows a case of total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation (TAPVC) with figure of 8 or snowman or cottage-loaf appearance .
  • • figure of 8 or snowman or cottage-loaf appearance
  • • TAPVC:
  • • TAPVC:
  • • TAPVC is a condition in which pulmonary veins drain directly or indirectly into the right atrium rather than the left atrium. As a result, pulmonary venous blood flow drains abnormally into the systemic venous circulation. It is a cyanotic heart disease with congestive heart failure symptoms. The patients are irritable and failure to thrive.
  • • TAPVC is a condition in which pulmonary veins drain directly or indirectly into the right atrium rather than the left atrium. As a result, pulmonary venous blood flow drains abnormally into the systemic venous circulation.
  • • pulmonary veins drain directly or indirectly into the right atrium rather than the left atrium.
  • • It is a cyanotic heart disease with congestive heart failure symptoms. The patients are irritable and failure to thrive.
  • • The patients are irritable and failure to thrive.
  • • The following types are seen:
  • • The following types are seen:
  • • I. Supra cardiac – Most common type
  • • I. Supra cardiac –
  • • II. Cardiac
  • • II. Cardiac
  • • III. Infra cardiac – Most common type for obstruction (worst prognosis)
  • • III. Infra cardiac –
  • • (worst prognosis)
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Cottage loaf, truncus arteriosus: Truncus arteriosus involves a single arterial trunk coming from the heart, not typically showing a snowman sign.
  • • Option A. Cottage loaf, truncus arteriosus:
  • • Option C. Egg on side, TGA (Transposition of the Great Arteries): This condition typically shows an "egg on a string" appearance due to the abnormal positioning of the great arteries.
  • • Option C. Egg on side, TGA (Transposition of the Great Arteries):
  • • Option D. Boot shaped heart, TOF (Tetralogy of Fallot): Characterized by a boot-shaped heart on X-ray due to right ventricular hypertrophy; not the pattern observed in this image.'
  • • Option D. Boot shaped heart, TOF (Tetralogy of Fallot):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The "snowman sign" on a chest X-ray in a child presenting with cyanosis and fatigue is highly suggestive of Supracardiac TAPVC.

questions.text: A farmer suffered from a subcutaneous wound on the dorsum of the foot which later involved the subcutaneous tissue and produced a discharging ulcer. Microscopic examination of the discharge showed gram-positive filamentous rods with branching. The organism responsible is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Nocardia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases involving subcutaneous infections with gram-positive filamentous rods and branching, consider Nocardia as the responsible organism, particularly in the context of actinomycetoma.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman is evaluated for primary infertility. Hysterosalpingography was done and reveals the finding shown below. What is the anomaly seen in the image? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Septate uterus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The anomaly seen in the given hysterosalpingogram is suggestive of a septate uterus. A septate uterus is characterized by the presence of a septum in the endometrial cavity which hasn’t disappeared after fusion of the 2 Mullerian ducts On HSG, a septate and bicornuate uterus are commonly mis-diagnosed If the angle between the 2 horns is <75, it is likely a septate uterus (As in this question) If the angle between the 2 horns is >105, then it is likely a bicornuate uterus However, an HSG is not the ideal ix of choice An MRI is the best Ix for Mullerian anomalies
  • • The anomaly seen in the given hysterosalpingogram is suggestive of a septate uterus.
  • • A septate uterus is characterized by the presence of a septum in the endometrial cavity which hasn’t disappeared after fusion of the 2 Mullerian ducts
  • • On HSG, a septate and bicornuate uterus are commonly mis-diagnosed
  • • If the angle between the 2 horns is <75, it is likely a septate uterus (As in this question)
  • • If the angle between the 2 horns is >105, then it is likely a bicornuate uterus
  • • However, an HSG is not the ideal ix of choice
  • • An MRI is the best Ix for Mullerian anomalies
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Uterine didelphys : Uterine didelphys appears as 2 completely separate uterine cavities on the HSG with no communication whatsoever
  • • Option B. Uterine didelphys
  • • Option C. Bicornuate uterus : Bicornuate uterus: This appears as 2 horns of the uterus which are widely separated (angle > 105 degree)
  • • Option C. Bicornuate uterus
  • • Option D. Unicornuate uterus : Unicornuate uterus: Single horn on the HSG
  • • Option D. Unicornuate uterus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The anomaly seen in the image is a septate uterus which is characterized by the presence of a septum in the endometrial cavity which hasn’t disappeared after fusion of the 2 Mullerian ducts.
  • ➤ The anomaly seen in the image is a septate uterus which
  • ➤ Ref: Page 47, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gyn 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 47, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gyn 6 th edition

questions.text: Patient came with fever and chills. Peripheral smear shown in the image. Choose the pathogen: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Plasmodium falciparum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: An 8-day-old newborn was found to have thyroid -stimulating hormone level of more than 100 mlU/L. Which of the following will be the next best investigation? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Radiotracer uptake with technetium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Radiotracer uptake with technetium is the next best investigation to confirm the presence and function of the thyroid gland in a newborn with elevated TSH.

questions.text: A 1-month-old baby presents with an olive-shaped mass and recurrent vomiting. An ultrasound (USG) was performed, as shown below. What is your diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) CHPS (Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ CHPS should be suspected in infants presenting with non-bilious projectile vomiting, an olive-shaped abdominal mass, and confirmed with ultrasound showing pyloric muscle thickening and elongation (typically 4 mm thickness and 16 mm length)

questions.text: Which of the following is earliest to rise in myocardial infarction? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ischemia modified albumin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In the event of a myocardial infarction, certain biomarkers are released into the bloodstream as a result of cardiac muscle injury.
  • • Among the three early markers of myocardial injury , three are particularly significant: myoglobin, heart-type fatty acid binding protein (HFABP), and ischemia modified albumin (IMA). Of these three, ischemia modified albumin is the earliest to rise and also the earliest to fall in response to myocardial ischemia. This rapid change makes it a valuable early diagnostic marker for detecting myocardial infarction.
  • • three early markers of myocardial injury
  • • myoglobin, heart-type fatty acid binding protein (HFABP), and ischemia modified albumin (IMA).
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Troponin: Troponins are highly specific markers for myocardial injury and are considered the gold standard for diagnosing myocardial infarction. However, they do not rise as early as ischemia modified albumin. Typically, troponin levels start to rise 4-6 hours after the onset of myocardial infarction.
  • • Option A. Troponin:
  • • Option C. LDH (Lactate Dehydrogenase): LDH is an enzyme found in almost all body tissues and is not specific to cardiac tissue. It is a later marker of myocardial infarction, usually rising within 24-48 hours after the onset of symptoms.
  • • Option C. LDH (Lactate Dehydrogenase):
  • • Option D. CK MB (Creatine Kinase-MB): CK-MB is a specific isoenzyme found in heart muscle and is used as a marker for myocardial infarction. However, it does not rise as early as ischemia modified albumin. CK-MB levels typically start to increase 3-6 hours after myocardial infarction.
  • • Option D. CK MB (Creatine Kinase-MB):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ischemia modified albumin is the earliest biomarker to rise in the event of a myocardial infarction, making it a crucial early indicator for diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is contraindicated in Iron overdose? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) BAL

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ BAL is contraindicated in iron overdose due to its potential to form harmful complexes, making Desferrioxamine the preferred treatment in such cases.

questions.text: After a fall from a height, a 10-year-old child presented to the emergency department with complaints of abdominal pain. Upon examination, the child's vital signs were stable, but tenderness was noted in the left lumbar region. What would be the best investigation of choice? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Contrast enhanced CT scan

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of suspected blunt renal trauma, particularly in a hemodynamically stable patient, a contrast-enhanced CT scan is the investigation of choice. This allows for detailed imaging of the abdomen to accurately diagnose and assess the extent of the injury.
  • ➤ In cases of suspected blunt renal trauma, particularly in a hemodynamically stable patient, a contrast-enhanced CT scan is the investigation of choice.
  • ➤ This allows for detailed imaging of the abdomen to accurately diagnose and assess the extent of the injury.

questions.text: A 65-year-old chronic smoker came to the medicine outpatient department with complaints of upper chest discomfort and drooping of an eyelid. He also complained of pain radiating to the upper arm and a tingling sensation in the 4th and 5th digits of his left hand. The chest X-ray is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pancoast tumor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pancoast tumors, or superior sulcus tumors, are associated with upper chest discomfort, Horner's syndrome, and neurological symptoms in the arm due to their apical location and propensity to invade local structures such as the brachial plexus and sympathetic nerves.

questions.text: Which of the following is a hexanucleotide repeat disorder? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Frontotemporal dementia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a history of HTN, DM2, and DLP is brought to the ER because of reports of palpitations and dizziness. ECG is ordered and shown in the image. His temperature is 36.8°C, PR is 106/min, RR is 18/min, BP is 84/46 mm Hg, and SpO2 is 92% on room air. What is the next step? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. DC shock

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In hemodynamically unstable patients with atrial fibrillation, immediate synchronized DC cardioversion is the next step to restore a stable rhythm and improve hemodynamic status.

questions.text: Desert rheumatism is caused by: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Coccidioides immitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Desert rheumatism (Valley fever or California fever) is caused by the fungus Coccidioides immitis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of cervical erosion and spotting since 2 months. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)  LBC + HPV + cervical biopsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a patient with cervical erosion and spotting, the best approach is to screen for cervical cancer with LBC, HPV testing, and a cervical biopsy if indicated.

questions.text: Hyperextension at MCP joint and flexion at IP joint occurs due to involvement of which muscle?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Lumbricals and interossei

questions.text: Most common site of nasopharyngeal carcinoma: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the fossa of Rosenmüller, located posterior to the torus tubarius in the nasopharynx.

questions.text: The recommended temperature of water bath for a patient with frost bite is? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. 37 degrees C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Frostbite should be rewarmed in circulating water at 37–40°C for 30–60 minutes, avoiding hot air or dry heat.

questions.text: A woman presents to OPD at 36 weeks of gestation and presents with complaints of breathlessness and excessive abdominal distension. On examination, fetal movements are normal, fetal parts not easily felt and muffled fetal heartbeat is heard. Symphysis fundal height came out to be 41 cm. Per abdomen examination reveals tense abdomen but not tender. What can be the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Polyhydramnios

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In a 36 weeks pregnant woman with breathlessness and excessive abdominal distension and fundal height 41 cm, it most likely points to a diagnosis of polyhydramnios.

questions.text: A 3-week-old infant is brought to OPD with complaints of cough and sore throat. The mother reports that the infant develops a paroxysm of cough followed by apnea. Blood investigations reveal total leucocyte count to be >50,000 cells/L. Which of the following drugs is appropriate for this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Azithromycin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For infants presenting with pertussis (whooping cough), characterized by paroxysmal cough and elevated leukocyte count, the drug of choice is azithromycin.

questions.text: A patient presented with the X-ray. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Miliary TB

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Miliary TB presents with numerous small, uniformly distributed nodules on a chest X-ray, resembling millet seeds. This pattern is a hallmark of disseminated tuberculosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of tubercular otitis media? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Earache

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Earache is notably absent in tubercular otitis media, differentiating it from other types of middle ear infections where pain is a common symptom. Recognizing the painless nature of this condition is crucial for prompt and accurate diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A lady from West Rajasthan presented with an ulcer surrounded by erythema on the right leg. Microscopy of the biopsy from the edge of the ulcer showed organisms with dark staining nuclei and kinetoplast. What is the most likely causative agent? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Leishmania tropica

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Leishmania tropica is the causative agent of cutaneous leishmaniasis, leading to skin ulcers that can be identified by microscopy showing organisms with kinetoplasts. Awareness of this condition is crucial for correct diagnosis and management, particularly in endemic areas like parts of Rajasthan, India.

questions.text: The remnants of Wolffian ducts in females are located in? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Leaves of broad ligament

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Leaves of broad ligament:
  • • Leaves of broad ligament:
  • • The Wolffian ducts, also known as mesonephric ducts, form the male genital tract in men. In females, the Mullerian duct forms the female internal genitalia, including the fallopian tubes, uterus, and the upper part of the vagina, while the Wolffian ducts atrophy. As the Wolffian ducts atrophy in females, they leave behind remnants located between the two layers of the broad ligament and in the anterolateral wall of the vagina. These remnants include: Hydatid cyst of Morgagni : Located lateral to the fallopian tube. Koblet’s tubules : Found in the outer part of the broad ligament. Epoophoron : Located between the ovary and the fallopian tube. Para-oophoron : Situated between the ovary and the uterus. Gartner’s duct : Located in the anterolateral wall of the vagina.
  • • The Wolffian ducts, also known as mesonephric ducts, form the male genital tract in men.
  • • In females, the Mullerian duct forms the female internal genitalia, including the fallopian tubes, uterus, and the upper part of the vagina, while the Wolffian ducts atrophy.
  • • As the Wolffian ducts atrophy in females, they leave behind remnants located between the two layers of the broad ligament and in the anterolateral wall of the vagina. These remnants include: Hydatid cyst of Morgagni : Located lateral to the fallopian tube. Koblet’s tubules : Found in the outer part of the broad ligament. Epoophoron : Located between the ovary and the fallopian tube. Para-oophoron : Situated between the ovary and the uterus. Gartner’s duct : Located in the anterolateral wall of the vagina.
  • • Hydatid cyst of Morgagni : Located lateral to the fallopian tube. Koblet’s tubules : Found in the outer part of the broad ligament. Epoophoron : Located between the ovary and the fallopian tube. Para-oophoron : Situated between the ovary and the uterus. Gartner’s duct : Located in the anterolateral wall of the vagina.
  • • Hydatid cyst of Morgagni : Located lateral to the fallopian tube.
  • • Hydatid cyst of Morgagni
  • • Koblet’s tubules : Found in the outer part of the broad ligament.
  • • Koblet’s tubules
  • • Epoophoron : Located between the ovary and the fallopian tube.
  • • Epoophoron
  • • Para-oophoron : Situated between the ovary and the uterus.
  • • Para-oophoron
  • • Gartner’s duct : Located in the anterolateral wall of the vagina.
  • • Gartner’s duct
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Pouch of Douglas: This is the rectouterine pouch, a space between the uterus and the rectum, and is not associated with remnants of the Wolffian ducts.
  • • Option A. Pouch of Douglas:
  • • Option C. Uterovesical pouch: This is the space between the uterus and the bladder and does not contain Wolffian duct remnants.
  • • Option C. Uterovesical pouch:
  • • Option D. Iliac fossa: This is an anatomical region of the pelvis, and it is not related to the remnants of the Wolffian ducts.
  • • Option D. Iliac fossa:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The remnants of the Wolffian ducts in females are found in the leaves of the broad ligament and the anterolateral wall of the vagina.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 47, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 47, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6 th edition

questions.text: In the below question mechanical receptors are given with their functions. Choose the correctly matched pair.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pacinian corpuscle - Fast Vibration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pacinian corpuscles are responsible for detecting fast vibrations, and Ruffini endings detect skin stretch.

questions.text: Cherry red spots on retina and mental retardation is seen in: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tay Sach’s disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The hallmark feature of Tay-Sachs disease is the presence of "cherry red spots" on the retina of the eye. These spots are a distinctive sign observed during eye examinations. Additionally, individuals with Tay-Sachs disease often experience progressive neurological deterioration, including muscle weakness, loss of motor skills, and seizures. There is also a characteristic decline in cognitive function, leading to intellectual and developmental disability.

References:

  • ↳ Reference : Harper’s 31 st ed/pg- 235

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with intermittent right upper quadrant pain and episodes of jaundice. Ultrasound shows multiple pigmented gallstones in the gallbladder. Laboratory tests reveal elevated bilirubin levels. Hemoglobin electrophoresis shows abnormal hemoglobin patterns. The patient has a history of beta-thalassemia minor. Which of the following is least likely to be associated with the formation of pigmented gallstones? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Beta-thalassemia minor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Beta-thalassemia minor (trait) is typically asymptomatic and not associated with significant hemolysis or pigmented gallstone formation, in contrast to other hemoglobinopathies like sickle cell disease that cause chronic hemolysis and increased bilirubin production .
  • ➤ sickle cell disease that cause chronic hemolysis and increased bilirubin production

questions.text: Which of the following drug used in ADHD is a Selective Norepinephrine Reuptake Inhibitor? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Reboxetine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Reboxetine is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (NRI) that can be used off-label for ADHD, distinct from other ADHD medications that target both norepinephrine and dopamine or act on other neurotransmitter systems.

questions.text: In which disease among the following, Chloride level in sweat is evaluated? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cystic fibrosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The chloride level in sweat is evaluated to diagnose cystic fibrosis, where elevated levels indicate the disease.

questions.text: Identify the vitamin deficiency: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:

questions.text: A man from Chhattisgarh presented with a gradual onset of muscle weakness and spasms in his legs. Upon examination, he exhibited a specific loss of motor function. What inquiries should be made to gather the most relevant medical history from this patient? (NEET PG 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: History of similar illness in the past

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) History of diet

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with pedal edema, abdominal distension, and distended neck veins. Chest X-ray is shown below. Which of the following will be seen? (FMGE JULY 2024)

options.label: B
options.text: SBP fall from 80 mm Hg to 60 mm Hg during inspiration

questions.correct_answer: B. SBP fall from 80 mm Hg to 60 mm Hg during inspiration
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) SBP fall from 80 mm Hg to 60 mm Hg during inspiration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cardiac tamponade is characterized by pulsus paradoxus, which is a significant drop in systolic blood pressure during inspiration, often exceeding 10 mm Hg

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl born out of non-consanguineous marriage presented with rachitic changes in limbs since 1½ years of age for which she has received multiple courses of vitamin D. Investigations showed the following. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hypophosphatemic rickets

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hypophosphatemic rickets is characterized by low serum phosphate, normal calcium and parathyroid hormone levels, and increased urinary phosphate due to renal phosphate wasting, commonly due to PHEX gene mutations.

questions.text: A patient was treated with repeated doses of IV anti-emetic for severe vomiting. The patient now does not have vomiting but developed abnormal movements. What is the most appropriate treatment? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Benzhexol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For patients who develop dystonic reactions after receiving anti-emetic medications like metoclopramide, the most appropriate treatment is an anticholinergic drug such as benzhexol (trihexyphenidyl). This helps alleviate the abnormal movements by restoring the balance between dopamine and acetylcholine in the central nervous system.

questions.text: In which condition both police and magistrate can do the inquest, but magistrate inquest will be preferred? (FMGE JAN 2025)

options.label: A
options.text: Family is not satisfied with police

questions.correct_answer: A. Family is not satisfied with police
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Family is not satisfied with police

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • An inquest is a legal investigation into the cause of death. In India, inquests are generally conducted under BNSS (formerly CrPC) . Two types of inquests exist:
  • • inquest
  • • BNSS (formerly CrPC)
  • • Two types of inquests
  • • Police Inquest (194 BNSS, earlier 174 CrPC): Conducted by the police officer (minimum rank: Head Constable). Most commonly used in cases of unnatural death (e.g., accidents, suicides, homicides). Magistrate Inquest (196 BNSS, earlier 176 CrPC): Conducted by an Executive or Judicial Magistrate . Mandatory in special cases such as: Dowry Deaths Custodial Deaths Exhumation (digging out a buried body) However, apart from above, in any case where usually the inquest is done by police, if a magistrate believes the police inquest was insufficient (e.g. family requests a magistrate-led inquest) , the magistrate can do additional inquest
  • • Police Inquest (194 BNSS, earlier 174 CrPC): Conducted by the police officer (minimum rank: Head Constable). Most commonly used in cases of unnatural death (e.g., accidents, suicides, homicides).
  • • Police Inquest (194 BNSS, earlier 174 CrPC):
  • • Conducted by the police officer (minimum rank: Head Constable). Most commonly used in cases of unnatural death (e.g., accidents, suicides, homicides).
  • • Conducted by the police officer (minimum rank: Head Constable).
  • • police officer
  • • Most commonly used in cases of unnatural death (e.g., accidents, suicides, homicides).
  • • unnatural death
  • • Magistrate Inquest (196 BNSS, earlier 176 CrPC): Conducted by an Executive or Judicial Magistrate . Mandatory in special cases such as: Dowry Deaths Custodial Deaths Exhumation (digging out a buried body) However, apart from above, in any case where usually the inquest is done by police, if a magistrate believes the police inquest was insufficient (e.g. family requests a magistrate-led inquest) , the magistrate can do additional inquest
  • • Magistrate Inquest (196 BNSS, earlier 176 CrPC):
  • • Conducted by an Executive or Judicial Magistrate . Mandatory in special cases such as: Dowry Deaths Custodial Deaths Exhumation (digging out a buried body) However, apart from above, in any case where usually the inquest is done by police, if a magistrate believes the police inquest was insufficient (e.g. family requests a magistrate-led inquest) , the magistrate can do additional inquest
  • • Conducted by an Executive or Judicial Magistrate .
  • • Executive or Judicial Magistrate
  • • Mandatory in special cases such as: Dowry Deaths Custodial Deaths Exhumation (digging out a buried body) However, apart from above, in any case where usually the inquest is done by police, if a magistrate believes the police inquest was insufficient (e.g. family requests a magistrate-led inquest) , the magistrate can do additional inquest
  • • Mandatory in special cases
  • • Dowry Deaths Custodial Deaths Exhumation (digging out a buried body) However, apart from above, in any case where usually the inquest is done by police, if a magistrate believes the police inquest was insufficient (e.g. family requests a magistrate-led inquest) , the magistrate can do additional inquest
  • • Dowry Deaths
  • • Dowry Deaths
  • • Custodial Deaths
  • • Custodial Deaths
  • • Exhumation (digging out a buried body)
  • • Exhumation (digging out a buried body)
  • • However, apart from above, in any case where usually the inquest is done by police, if a magistrate believes the police inquest was insufficient (e.g. family requests a magistrate-led inquest) , the magistrate can do additional inquest
  • • , the magistrate can do additional inquest
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Death in police custody: Incorrect
  • • Option B. Death in police custody: Incorrect
  • • Only a Magistrate inquest is allowed (196 BNSS, earlier 176 CrPC). Police cannot conduct an inquest in custodial deaths ​
  • • Only a Magistrate inquest is allowed (196 BNSS, earlier 176 CrPC).
  • • Only a Magistrate inquest is allowed
  • • Police cannot conduct an inquest in custodial deaths ​
  • • Police cannot conduct an inquest in custodial deaths
  • • cannot
  • • custodial deaths
  • • ​
  • • Option C. Dowry death: Incorrect
  • • Option C. Dowry death: Incorrect
  • • Only a Magistrate inquest is allowed (196 BNSS, earlier 176 CrPC). Dowry deaths must be investigated by a Magistrate , not the police
  • • Only a Magistrate inquest is allowed (196 BNSS, earlier 176 CrPC).
  • • Only a Magistrate inquest is allowed
  • • Dowry deaths must be investigated by a Magistrate , not the police
  • • must
  • • Magistrate
  • • Option D. Death by firing: Incorrect
  • • Option D. Death by firing: Incorrect
  • • Only a Police inquest is done (194 BNSS, earlier 174 CrPC) . A Magistrate inquest is not mandatory in cases of death by firing​
  • • Only a Police inquest is done (194 BNSS, earlier 174 CrPC) .
  • • Only a Police inquest is done (194 BNSS, earlier 174 CrPC)
  • • A Magistrate inquest is not mandatory in cases of death by firing​
  • • Magistrate inquest is not mandatory

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ If the family is not satisfied with a police inquest , they can appeal for a Magistrate inquest , which will be preferred to ensure justice . However, custodial deaths and dowry deaths require mandatory Magistrate inquests , while deaths by firing are handled by police inquests ​
  • ➤ family is not satisfied
  • ➤ police inquest
  • ➤ Magistrate inquest
  • ➤ preferred to ensure justice

questions.text: A 32-year-old healthcare worker presents with fatigue, low-grade fever, and mild right upper quadrant discomfort for the past 2 weeks. He reports a needlestick injury 3 months ago while drawing blood from a patient with unknown hepatitis status. Physical examination reveals mild icterus and tender hepatomegaly. Laboratory investigations show elevated ALT and AST levels. Serological testing shows the presence of HBsAg and IgM anti-HBc. What does the presence of IgM anti-HBc indicate? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Acute infection

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ IgM anti-HBc is the key serological marker for diagnosing acute hepatitis B infection, especially when accompanied by HBsAg and elevated liver enzymes.

questions.text: During laparoscopic surgery, which vessels are most prone to injury while inserting trocars? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Both B and C (Inferior Epigastric Artery & Superior Epigastric Artery)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • During laparoscopic surgery , trocars are inserted through the abdominal wall , and the most commonly injured vessels are epigastric arteries , specifically:
  • • laparoscopic surgery
  • • abdominal wall
  • • most commonly injured vessels
  • • epigastric arteries
  • • Inferior Epigastric Artery (IEA) → Runs posterior to the rectus abdominis , arising from the external iliac artery . It is commonly injured during trocar placement at the lateral ports (midclavicular line or lateral to rectus muscle) . Superior Epigastric Artery (SEA) → Arises from the internal thoracic artery , supplying the upper abdominal wall . It is less commonly injured but still at risk in upper trocar insertions near the midline .
  • • Inferior Epigastric Artery (IEA) → Runs posterior to the rectus abdominis , arising from the external iliac artery . It is commonly injured during trocar placement at the lateral ports (midclavicular line or lateral to rectus muscle) .
  • • Inferior Epigastric Artery (IEA)
  • • posterior to the rectus abdominis
  • • external iliac artery
  • • trocar placement at the lateral ports (midclavicular line or lateral to rectus muscle)
  • • Superior Epigastric Artery (SEA) → Arises from the internal thoracic artery , supplying the upper abdominal wall . It is less commonly injured but still at risk in upper trocar insertions near the midline .
  • • Superior Epigastric Artery (SEA)
  • • internal thoracic artery
  • • upper abdominal wall
  • • upper trocar insertions near the midline
  • • Risk factors
  • • Risk factors
  • • Inferior epigastric artery (IEA) runs lateral to the rectus muscle. Most laparoscopic trocars are placed in the periumbilical region and lateral ports, near IEA’s path. Injury to these vessels can lead to significant bleeding or hematoma formation, especially retroperitoneal hematoma.
  • • Inferior epigastric artery (IEA) runs lateral to the rectus muscle.
  • • Most laparoscopic trocars are placed in the periumbilical region and lateral ports, near IEA’s path.
  • • Injury to these vessels can lead to significant bleeding or hematoma formation, especially retroperitoneal hematoma.
  • • Other Option:
  • • Other Option:
  • • Option A. Abdominal Aorta → Incorrect
  • • Option A. Abdominal Aorta
  • • Incorrect
  • • The aorta is a retroperitoneal structure , located deep in the abdomen . It is not commonly injured during standard trocar placement unless there is misplacement of a Veress needle or excessive force .
  • • The aorta is a retroperitoneal structure , located deep in the abdomen .
  • • aorta is a retroperitoneal structure
  • • deep in the abdomen
  • • It is not commonly injured during standard trocar placement unless there is misplacement of a Veress needle or excessive force .
  • • not commonly injured during standard trocar placement
  • • misplacement of a Veress needle or excessive force

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Inferior and Superior Epigastric Arteries are the most commonly injured vessels during laparoscopic trocar insertion. Using transillumination and proper trocar placement can prevent vascular injury.
  • ➤ Management of Epigastric Artery Injury:
  • ➤ Management of Epigastric Artery Injury:
  • ➤ Preventive Measure : Use transillumination to identify epigastric vessels before inserting trocars. Place lateral trocars either lateral or medial to epigastric artery path. If Injury Occurs: Immediate control using electrocautery or direct pressure.
  • ➤ Preventive Measure : Use transillumination to identify epigastric vessels before inserting trocars. Place lateral trocars either lateral or medial to epigastric artery path.
  • ➤ Preventive Measure
  • ➤ Use transillumination to identify epigastric vessels before inserting trocars. Place lateral trocars either lateral or medial to epigastric artery path.
  • ➤ Use transillumination to identify epigastric vessels before inserting trocars.
  • ➤ Place lateral trocars either lateral or medial to epigastric artery path.
  • ➤ If Injury Occurs: Immediate control using electrocautery or direct pressure.
  • ➤ If Injury Occurs:
  • ➤ Immediate control using electrocautery or direct pressure.
  • ➤ Immediate control using electrocautery or direct pressure.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy was brought to the ER with complaints of melena. The child had intermittent pain in the right iliac region. On surgical exploration, the following was found. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Meckel’s diverticulum

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Meckel’s Diverticulum:
  • • Meckel’s Diverticulum:
  • • Congenital anomaly resulting from incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct . Rule of 2’s: Found in 2% of the population . 2 feet from the ileocecal valve . 2 inches long . 2 types of ectopic mucosa (gastric & pancreatic). 2:1 male predominance . Complications: Bleeding (painless hematochezia/melena) due to acid secretion from ectopic gastric mucosa , leading to ulceration. Intestinal obstruction (due to volvulus or intussusception). Diverticulitis , mimicking appendicitis.
  • • Congenital anomaly resulting from incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct .
  • • Congenital anomaly
  • • incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct
  • • Rule of 2’s: Found in 2% of the population . 2 feet from the ileocecal valve . 2 inches long . 2 types of ectopic mucosa (gastric & pancreatic). 2:1 male predominance .
  • • Rule of 2’s:
  • • Found in 2% of the population . 2 feet from the ileocecal valve . 2 inches long . 2 types of ectopic mucosa (gastric & pancreatic). 2:1 male predominance .
  • • Found in 2% of the population .
  • • 2% of the population
  • • 2 feet from the ileocecal valve .
  • • 2 feet from the ileocecal valve
  • • 2 inches long .
  • • 2 inches long
  • • 2 types of ectopic mucosa (gastric & pancreatic).
  • • 2 types of ectopic mucosa
  • • 2:1 male predominance .
  • • 2:1 male predominance
  • • Complications: Bleeding (painless hematochezia/melena) due to acid secretion from ectopic gastric mucosa , leading to ulceration. Intestinal obstruction (due to volvulus or intussusception). Diverticulitis , mimicking appendicitis.
  • • Complications:
  • • Bleeding (painless hematochezia/melena) due to acid secretion from ectopic gastric mucosa , leading to ulceration. Intestinal obstruction (due to volvulus or intussusception). Diverticulitis , mimicking appendicitis.
  • • Bleeding (painless hematochezia/melena) due to acid secretion from ectopic gastric mucosa , leading to ulceration.
  • • Bleeding (painless hematochezia/melena)
  • • acid secretion from ectopic gastric mucosa
  • • Intestinal obstruction (due to volvulus or intussusception).
  • • Intestinal obstruction
  • • Diverticulitis , mimicking appendicitis.
  • • Diverticulitis , mimicking appendicitis.
  • • Diverticulitis
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Obstructed Bowel Loops → Incorrect
  • • Option B. Obstructed Bowel Loops
  • • Would present with bilious vomiting, abdominal distension, and absent bowel sounds . No mention of melena or ectopic gastric tissue .
  • • Would present with bilious vomiting, abdominal distension, and absent bowel sounds .
  • • bilious vomiting, abdominal distension, and absent bowel sounds
  • • No mention of melena or ectopic gastric tissue .
  • • melena or ectopic gastric tissue
  • • Option C. Appendicitis → Incorrect
  • • Option C. Appendicitis
  • • While pain is in the right iliac fossa , melena is not a feature of appendicitis . Would present with fever, localized tenderness, rebound tenderness, and leukocytosis .
  • • While pain is in the right iliac fossa , melena is not a feature of appendicitis .
  • • right iliac fossa
  • • melena is not a feature of appendicitis
  • • Would present with fever, localized tenderness, rebound tenderness, and leukocytosis .
  • • fever, localized tenderness, rebound tenderness, and leukocytosis
  • • Option D. Appendicular Mucocele → Incorrect
  • • Option D. Appendicular Mucocele
  • • A mucocele is a mucus-filled dilatation of the appendix , usually seen in adults . Presents as a mass in the right iliac fossa , but not with melena .
  • • A mucocele is a mucus-filled dilatation of the appendix , usually seen in adults .
  • • mucocele
  • • mucus-filled dilatation of the appendix
  • • adults
  • • Presents as a mass in the right iliac fossa , but not with melena .
  • • mass in the right iliac fossa
  • • not with melena

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ It presents with painless lower gastrointestinal bleeding due to ectopic gastric mucosa, mimicking appendicitis. Diagnosis is confirmed by Meckel’s scan, and treatment is surgical resection in symptomatic cases.
